title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: But it was too wet to lie in the open, and she could not bring herself to knock at the doors of Duntarvie.

author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Duntarvie lay two miles farther on, still uphill, at the end of its own steep and rocky road which, being tree-embowered for the last fifty yards or so had always been known to the children as the " Avenue."

snippet: But this was as nothing to the news of Duntarvie that she brought with her out of that cavern of boots and breeches.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Not before she entered (and Joanna did enter, for in Tweedie's she knew she would learn whatever was to be known of Duntarvie and its present owners) would she have discovered that old sandy-haired Tweedie was dead, and that young sandy-haired Tweedie, already a bald-headed man was the master.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Every moment established her belief that Duntarvie was a real place after all, and her companion's praise of the countryside gave her keen joy.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Yet Joanna was happier than she knew; and as the train came nearer and nearer to Duntarvie, she grew eager in pointing out each well-remembered  landmark.

snippet: " See your Duntarvie if you must.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: But in the middle of her talk of Duntarvie, she became aware that Carl was looking at her with a thoughtfulness not caused by her words.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: She was all the more anxious to go to Duntarvie to make sure beyond a doubt whether a certain white-washed house and red-tiled steading  had once stood in a fold of moorland.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: It lay little more than five miles from Duntarvie,  so that she had been there many a time.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Duntarvie, Duntarvie! Would the stream still be flowing clear brown, and its furry stones be sheltering the spotted trout?

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Duntarvie, Duntarvie! Would the stream still be flowing clear brown, and its furry stones be sheltering the spotted trout?

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: At Perth Joanna saw her aunt drive off in a hired carriage, and herself returning to the booking-office, she took her ticket to the village from which Duntarvie was but three miles distant.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: If her niece really wanted to re-visit Duntarvie, why not do so that day?

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Duntarvie.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Incredible as it may seem, she had never thought of Duntarvie  as having a place upon the map.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: It was only then that there came to her as a perfect astonishment,  what she must long before have known, had her childish geography not been of the haziest and never amended Westermuir  lay within twenty miles of Duntarvie!

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: At Duntarvie, long ago, her bed had stood within hearing of the house cistern.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: She was almost speechless with shyness; but as they were sitting alone together at Duntarvie, drinking cups of chocolate before starting for town to buy young Sholto's " shortings," she managed to put into poor words some part of her mid-night thoughts.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Why then should his eyes recall so strongly the very look of the pools in the burn at Duntarvie?

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: No dwelling in her experience not the house at Collessie Street, not the brown villa at San Gervasio, not the whitewashed farm of Duntarvie itself had been so dear to her as this was going to be, this place in London of her own finding.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Nevertheless its mistress had caused the name Duntarvie to be painted in clear letters upon the gate.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: In her immediate, joyful agreement she certainly had Louis again in mind, but she had also in mind her beloved rough-coated pony of the Duntarvie days.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: which had come in childhood when she climbed high up on a dangerous place or ran barefoot from stone to stone with perilous gathering momentum down the Duntarvie burn.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Up to the left, beyond a hilly field, a fringe of trees ran along a crest of high ground, and they were like the trees on the way to the Upper Pond at Duntarvie.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: For the first time since she had lain by the margin of the upper pond at Duntarvie, she found herself able to look full upon beauty without grieving.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: At Duntarvie she had been in close touch with nature.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: He often came across the hill to help with odd jobs at Duntarvie, and in a sense was the children's playmate.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Yet another incident which made its mark on the still folded woman in Joanna, belonged to this time at Duntarvie.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Gerald, only son of Aunt Perdy, was a soldier, and he was recovering from fever caught in India when Juley invited him to Duntarvie.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: " If I forget thee O Duntarvie! " she whispered, " let my right hand forget its cunning."

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Their last summer at Duntarvie was that before Sholto's death.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: To the children there was music in the very name of the village from which Duntarvie was three miles distant uphill.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: The children owed Duntarvie which was a real place as well as Joanna's home of dreams to their mother.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: And for her " The Country " and every one of its joys was summed up in the single word Duntarvie.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Mabel was only too glad to be invited to Duntarvie in the holidays and to wear Georgie's outgrown muslins.

title: Open the door,
author: Carswell, Catherine MacFarlane
snippet: Better than games, better than being with his children, better than shooting capercailzie and rabbits at Duntarvie, their house in Perthshire, better than his curbed enjoyment of his wife's virginal freshness, was to him the elevation of a platform.
